revision.text:
<big><center><big><font color="#0066CC">'''PEER REVIEW FEEDBACK'''</big></big></font> *Use this template to grade the peer reviews you receive.</center>
Directions
*Use this rubric to evaluate EACH peer review you receive for your article. *You will award points for each of the sections in this rubric. *Write the scores below in the section called "Scores". *Your evaluation will determine your reviewer's grade for this assignment; please take your time and grade honestly and fairly. -----------------
{| border="1" |+ <big> '''Foundations Wiki Article Peer Review Feedback: Grading Rubric''' </big> |<center>'''Assessment Criterion'''|| <center>'''Level of Performance''' ||. || . || |- | . || <center>Complete (30) || <center>Incomplete (0-29)||.|| |- | <center>'''Includes All Components''' || Feedback is provided for ALL of the following sections: *Learning targets (2 points) *Multiple-choice questions (2 points) *Sources (2 points) *Rating (2 points) *Explanation of rating (5 points) *Grammar/mechanics (5 points) *Includes two compliments (4 points) *Includes two suggestions (4 points) *Contains 150 words total or more (4 points) ||The full point value should be deducted for any missing components. Partial credit can be awarded for incomplete components. ||. |- | . || <center>'''Above Average 5'''|| <center>''' Average 4'''|| <center>'''Needs Improvement 0 to 3'''|| |- | . || . || .||.|| |- |- |<center>'''Reflects Standards or Criteria'''|| Feedback specifically describes how the paper meets or does not meet the criteria listed in the rubric|| Feedback generally relates to the criteria listed in the rubric|| Feedback is unrelated to the criteria listed in the rubric|| |- |<center>'''Understandable''' || Feedback is written in a clear and direct manner that is easy to understand || Some of the feedback is clear; some is vague, confusing or difficult to understand || The feedback is vague, confusing or difficult to understand || |- |<center>'''Specific'''||Many specific passages in the text are referred to as strengths and/or weaknesses||At least one specific passage in the text is noted as a strength or weaknesses; much of the feedback is general||The feedback is general; it does not reference specific passages of the text as strong or weak points|| |- |<center>'''Achievable'''||The feedback is positively stated and includes several suggestions that can be reasonably made by the author to improve the quality of the article||The feedback contains at least one reasonable suggestion; may also contain suggestions that are unrealistic given the capabilities of the author/the time allotted for revision||Feedback contains no specific suggestions to achieve or only contains suggestions that are unrealistic given the capabilities of the author/the time allotted for revision|| |- |.|| .|| . || .||
|}
== SCORES ==
*Includes all components: _____<u>30</u>_ / 30
*Reflects Standards or Criteria: __<u>5</u>_____ / 5
*Understandable: ____<u>5</u>___ / 5
*Specific: ____<u>4</u>___ / 5
*Achievable: ____<u>5</u>___ / 5
TOTAL SCORE: ___<u>49</u>____ /50
== Comments (1 + 1) ==
Provide ONE compliment and ONE suggestion for your peer reviewer. For example, what did you find most or least effective? What would make the feedback more effective?
COMPLIMENT: I liked how you were very thorough on each section. You were not affraid to say exactly what you thought and so that helps me see how the article is percieved by others.
SUGGESTION: I wish you would ahve picked a different color to write the review in, after reading for a while the pink was hurting my eyes.
EFFECTIVE: I found effective that you clearly stated what specific areas I needed to work on the article and how you provide some words of encouragement at teh end. Nice touch!
MORE EFFECTIVE: To have given an exact example of what you meant by "sentences are to wordy", Hcomb003.
[[User:Bpenn005|Bpenn005]] ([[User talk:Bpenn005|talk]]) 00:03, 22 June 2009 (UTC)

Directions
*Use this rubric to evaluate EACH peer review you receive for your article. *You will award points for each of the sections in this rubric. *Write the scores below in the section called "Scores". *Your evaluation will determine your reviewer's grade for this assignment; please take your time and grade honestly and fairly. -----------------
{| border="1" |+ <big> '''Foundations Wiki Article Peer Review Feedback: Grading Rubric''' </big> |<center>'''Assessment Criterion'''|| <center>'''Level of Performance''' ||. || . || |- | . || <center>Complete (30) || <center>Incomplete (0-29)||.|| |- | <center>'''Includes All Components''' || Feedback is provided for ALL of the following sections: *Learning targets (2 points) *Multiple-choice questions (2 points) *Sources (2 points) *Rating (2 points) *Explanation of rating (5 points) *Grammar/mechanics (5 points) *Includes two compliments (4 points) *Includes two suggestions (4 points) *Contains 150 words total or more (4 points) ||The full point value should be deducted for any missing components. Partial credit can be awarded for incomplete components. ||. |- | . || <center>'''Above Average 5'''|| <center>''' Average 4'''|| <center>'''Needs Improvement 0 to 3'''|| |- | . || . || .||.|| |- |- |<center>'''Reflects Standards or Criteria'''|| Feedback specifically describes how the paper meets or does not meet the criteria listed in the rubric|| Feedback generally relates to the criteria listed in the rubric|| Feedback is unrelated to the criteria listed in the rubric|| |- |<center>'''Understandable''' || Feedback is written in a clear and direct manner that is easy to understand || Some of the feedback is clear; some is vague, confusing or difficult to understand || The feedback is vague, confusing or difficult to understand || |- |<center>'''Specific'''||Many specific passages in the text are referred to as strengths and/or weaknesses||At least one specific passage in the text is noted as a strength or weaknesses; much of the feedback is general||The feedback is general; it does not reference specific passages of the text as strong or weak points|| |- |<center>'''Achievable'''||The feedback is positively stated and includes several suggestions that can be reasonably made by the author to improve the quality of the article||The feedback contains at least one reasonable suggestion; may also contain suggestions that are unrealistic given the capabilities of the author/the time allotted for revision||Feedback contains no specific suggestions to achieve or only contains suggestions that are unrealistic given the capabilities of the author/the time allotted for revision|| |- |.|| .|| . || .||
|}
== SCORES ==
*Includes all components: _<u>30</u>_ / 30
*Reflects Standards or Criteria: _<u>5</u> / 5
*Understandable: _<u>5</u>_ / 5
*Specific: _<u>5</u>_ / 5
*Achievable: _<u>4</u>_ / 5
TOTAL SCORE: _<u>49</u>_ /50
== Comments (1 + 1) ==
Provide ONE compliment and ONE suggestion for your peer reviewer. For example, what did you find most or least effective? What would make the feedback more effective?
COMPLIMENT: I really liked how you were very specific about certain suggestions on areas of the feedback. I also likes when you mentioned that I was picking your brain presenting pondering questions in my introduction. That is the reaction I wanted to create in any potential reader.
SUGGESTION: I think you should have used Caps along with bold letter for your review.
EFFECTIVE: I liked how you suggested to include more information on the articles to be able to comprehend the learning targets.
[[User:Bpenn005|Bpenn005]] ([[User talk:Bpenn005|talk]]) 00:21, 22 June 2009 (UTC)

Directions
*Use this rubric to evaluate EACH peer review you receive for your article. *You will award points for each of the sections in this rubric. *Write the scores below in the section called "Scores". *Your evaluation will determine your reviewer's grade for this assignment; please take your time and grade honestly and fairly. -----------------
{| border="1" |+ <big> '''Foundations Wiki Article Peer Review Feedback: Grading Rubric''' </big> |<center>'''Assessment Criterion'''|| <center>'''Level of Performance''' ||. || . || |- | . || <center>Complete (30) || <center>Incomplete (0-29)||.|| |- | <center>'''Includes All Components''' || Feedback is provided for ALL of the following sections: *Learning targets (2 points) *Multiple-choice questions (2 points) *Sources (2 points) *Rating (2 points) *Explanation of rating (5 points) *Grammar/mechanics (5 points) *Includes two compliments (4 points) *Includes two suggestions (4 points) *Contains 150 words total or more (4 points) ||The full point value should be deducted for any missing components. Partial credit can be awarded for incomplete components. ||. |- | . || <center>'''Above Average 5'''|| <center>''' Average 4'''|| <center>'''Needs Improvement 0 to 3'''|| |- | . || . || .||.|| |- |- |<center>'''Reflects Standards or Criteria'''|| Feedback specifically describes how the paper meets or does not meet the criteria listed in the rubric|| Feedback generally relates to the criteria listed in the rubric|| Feedback is unrelated to the criteria listed in the rubric|| |- |<center>'''Understandable''' || Feedback is written in a clear and direct manner that is easy to understand || Some of the feedback is clear; some is vague, confusing or difficult to understand || The feedback is vague, confusing or difficult to understand || |- |<center>'''Specific'''||Many specific passages in the text are referred to as strengths and/or weaknesses||At least one specific passage in the text is noted as a strength or weaknesses; much of the feedback is general||The feedback is general; it does not reference specific passages of the text as strong or weak points|| |- |<center>'''Achievable'''||The feedback is positively stated and includes several suggestions that can be reasonably made by the author to improve the quality of the article||The feedback contains at least one reasonable suggestion; may also contain suggestions that are unrealistic given the capabilities of the author/the time allotted for revision||Feedback contains no specific suggestions to achieve or only contains suggestions that are unrealistic given the capabilities of the author/the time allotted for revision|| |- |.|| .|| . || .||
|}
== SCORES ==
*Includes all components: 30 / 30
*Reflects Standards or Criteria: 5 / 5
*Understandable: 5 / 5
*Specific: 5 / 5
*Achievable: 5 / 5
TOTAL SCORE: 50 /50
== Comments (1 + 1) == I enjoyed reading your comments. I thought each one was very helpful. I noticed a couple of grammatical errors I made after my article had been peer reviewed. I would just make sure to look over the articles more than once to make sure nothing was overlooked. Thank you for all your comments. I found them very helpful.
Provide ONE compliment and ONE suggestion for your peer reviewer. For example, what did you find most or least effective? What would make the feedback more effective?

I would possibly check the article I was reviewing a few times to make sure I did not miss anything. Other than that I appreciate everything said and found. Thank you!
Provide ONE compliment and ONE suggestion for your peer reviewer. For example, what did you find most or least effective? What would make the feedback more effective?

== Comments (1 + 1) ==
Provide ONE compliment and ONE suggestion for your peer reviewer. For example, what did you find most or least effective? What would make the feedback more effective?
The author of my peer review was effective about choosing which section of the paper to edit.....Instead of copying the whole paper and editing the whole paper, the reviewer chose a paragraph that was viewed as being most in need of revisions. The reviewer then added some helpful reviews to this paragraph....
Suggestion: the reviewer could have given some additional comments on mechanics and grammar rather than just giving edits of a pasted paragraph.
[[User:Mbrowder|Mbrowder]] ([[User talk:Mbrowder|talk]]) 19:52, 22 July 2009 (UTC)

== Comments (1 + 1) ==
Provide ONE compliment and ONE suggestion for your peer reviewer. For example, what did you find most or least effective? What would make the feedback more effective?
I considered many things from this particular feedback. I revised my learning targets and some grammatical errors. I felt like I did consider my bias in sources, although I could have provided the other side to the federal curriculum debate. However, that is a paper on its own. I simply tried to present the issue as a current debate without giving any of my opinions. I also changed my fourth multiple choice question accordingly. Thanks. [[User:Abitt002|Abitt002]] ([[User talk:Abitt002|talk]]) 23:09, 17 June 2009 (UTC)

There were some good, specific suggestions at the end of the review. I found this most effective, and I liked the specific suggestion to remove some of the sources for the reader to investigate on their own.
Please provide more specific detailed feedback throughout the entire peer review. I greatly appriciate your rating, but please offer some feedback as to why I received each rating in the areas of importantance, interest, credibility and writing skill. Thank you!

*Reflects Standards or Criteria: 5 / 5
*Understandable: 5 / 5
*Specific: 5 / 5
*Achievable: 5 / 5
TOTAL SCORE: 50 /50
== Comments (1 + 1) ==
Provide ONE compliment and ONE suggestion for your peer reviewer. For example, what did you find most or least effective? What would make the feedback more effective?
Compliment: The most effective thing was pointing out the careless spelling and grammar errors that I tend to commonly make.
Suggestion: For the corrections in my actual article, if they could not only be in all caps, but also in another color. It's still hard to find them when they're black.
[[User:Sbutl016|Sbutl016]] ([[User talk:Sbutl016|talk]]) 18:19, 14 June 2009 (UTC)

* Reflects Standards or Criteria: <font color=#0066CC> 5 </font color> / 5
* Understandable: <font color=#0066CC> 5 </font color>/ 5
* Specific: <font color=#0066CC> 5 </font color> / 5
* Achievable: <font color=#0066CC> 5 </font color> / 5
TOTAL SCORE: <font color=#0066CC> 50 </font color> /50
== Comments (1 + 1) ==
Provide ONE compliment and ONE suggestion for your peer reviewer. For example, what did you find most or least effective? What would make the feedback more effective?
Your suggestion on modification of my learning targets lead me to reevaluate them. I rewrote two targets to make them more specific.
While I understand your concern about the formatting of my citations and the use of older materials, APA guidelines state how to format a source found within a source. I followed those guidelines while citing my sources. Those same guidelines require I list the secondard source in my references, which is where the old sources come into play. In actuality, my source is dated 2006 with secondary sources listed with a later date. Just trying to keep the professor happy and myself on the right side of the law!
Thanks for the grammar and mechanics check. I would suggest copying the article and placing the just the corrections in another color. They are easier to locate when they jump out at you.
Great work! [[User:Acrow005|Acrow005]] ([[User talk:Acrow005|talk]]) 01:17, 17 June 2009 (UTC)

Your suggestions were clear and concise. I am especially grateful for your thorough grammar check. It is always good to have a second (and third) set of eyes. I amended my article and it flows nicely. Thanks!
While I understand your concern about the formatting of my citations and the use of older materials, APA guidelines state how to format a source found within a source. Your comments were excellent. Try not to type them in all CAPS. While I appreciate the comments and suggestions, they go down easier if they aren't "shouted" at you.
Great work! [[User:Acrow005|Acrow005]] ([[User talk:Acrow005|talk]]) 01:30, 17 June 2009 (UTC)

TOTAL SCORE: _____49__ /50 [[User:Rburt005|Rburt005]] ([[User talk:Rburt005|talk]]) 05:01, 16 June 2009 (UTC)
== Comments (1 + 1) == I FOUND THAT THE SUGGESTIONS YOU PROVIDED FOR IMPROVEMENT WERE GREAT. IT REALLY MADE ME LOOK AT THE ARTICLE AGAIN AND SEE IT FROM A DIFFERENT PERSPECTIVE THAN MY OWN. BRINGING MY ATTENTION TO THE CITATIONS WAS DEFINITELY A GOOD THING BECAUSE SOMETIMES THAT IS NOT MY STRONGEST AREA. I FOUND THIS TO BE MOST EFFECTIVE AS FEEDBACK BECAUSE OFTEN AS THE AUTHOR, IT IS HARD TO ACCEPT CRITIQUES ESPECIALLY IF YOU FEEL YOUR ARTICLE IS FINE JUST THE WAY IT IS. SO I DEFINITELY WELCOMED ALL SUGGESTIONS YOU MADE, AND THEY WERE ALL VALID AND I AM GLAD YOU CAN HELP IMPROVE MY ARTICLE!
MY ONLY SUGGESTION WOULD BE TO ADD MORE SPECIFIC DETAILS ABOUT WHAT NEEDS TO BE FIXED OR CHANGED WITHIN THE ARTICLE.TO MAKE THE FEEDBACK MORE EFFECTIVE IT COULD INCLUDE SPECIFIC PASSAGES OR QUOTES THAT NEED TO BE ADDRESSED, OR SPECIFYING WHAT ADDITIONAL CITATIONS NEED TO BE FIXED BESIDES THE ONE COPIED AND PASTED. OTHER THAN THAT GREAT FEEDBACK, I REALLY ENJOYED WHAT YOU HAD TO SAY ABOUT MY ARTICLE! :) [[User:Rburt005|Rburt005]] ([[User talk:Rburt005|talk]]) 05:00, 16 June 2009 (UTC)
Provide ONE compliment and ONE suggestion for your peer reviewer. For example, what did you find most or least effective? What would make the feedback more effective?

== Comments (1 + 1) I FELT YOU DID A GREAT JOB PEER REVIEWING MY ARTICLE. LISTENING TO YOUR FEEDBACK I COULD REALLY SEE WHAT THINGS I NEEDED TO CHANGE THE MOST AND PUT MORE ATTENTION TO. I ALSO UNDERSTAND THE OUTDATED SOURCES, AND APPRECIATE THE COMPLIMENT ON THE DIVERSITY OF THE SOURCES! I FELT YOU PROVIDED SPECIFIC DETAILED FEEDBACK, AND I THINK IT WILL HELP TO IMPROVE MY ARTICLE GREATLY!
THERE IS NOT REALLY MANY SUGGESTIONS I CAN THINK OF FOR YOU TO DO, BUT ONE THING WOULD BE TO ADD A LITTLE MORE TO THE DESCRIPTION OF ADDING NEWER SOURCES. revision.comment: ==Framework approach and Strategy== updated
revision.text: [[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]] {{Navigate |Book=Business Intelligence |Curr=Understand strategy |Prev=Framing stage |Next=Clarify strategy}} {{cquote|An ongoing process that evaluates and controls the business and the industries in which the company is involved; assesses its competitors and sets goals and strategies to meet all existing and potential competitors; and then reassesses each strategy annually or quarterly [i.e. regularly] to determine how it has been implemented and whether it has succeeded or needs replacement by a new strategy to meet changed circumstances, new technology, new competitors, a new economic environment., or a new social, financial, or political environment.|||Lamb 1984}} ==What is strategy?== Lamb offers an important definition of strategy. Strategy is also:[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corporate_strategy Strategic management] {{cquote|Drafting, implementing and evaluating cross-functional decisions that will enable an organization to achieve its long-term objectives. It is the process of specifying the organization's mission, vision and objectives, developing policies and plans, often in terms of projects and programs, which are designed to achieve these objectives, and then allocating resources to implement the policies and plans, projects and programs.||| David 1989}} This book focuses on strategic management. Strategy is an ongoing process that develops both long-term and short-term objectives at the strategic and operational levels, establishes and/or modifies the organizational hierarchy to manage operational processes, and determines the suitability, feasibility and acceptability of the strategy. An explicit way to represent the corporate strategy is using strategy diagrams. Strategy diagrams aid in all aspects of strategic management. They allow us to explicitly capture strategic and operational objectives. Cascading the strategy through the organizational hierarchy provides a means to align strategy with operations. Finally, using strategy diagrams makes it possible to evaluate the strategy by determining if it is being successfully implemented and if it is the correct strategy. An effective BI system must aid in all aspects of strategic management, including the formulation, implementation and evaluation of strategy. ==Strategic Management== For our purposes we will define strategic management as a combination of three main processes: #Strategy formulation #Strategy implementation #Strategy evaluation ===Strategy formulation=== Strategy formulation requires examining where you are now, determining where you want to go, and then determining how to get there. This requires the following three processes: [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corporate_strategy] *Performing a situation analysis, self-evaluation and competitor analysis: both internal and external; both micro-environmental and macro-environmental. *Concurrent with this assessment, objectives are set. These objectives should be parallel to a timeline; some are in the short-term and others on the long-term. This involves crafting vision statements (long term view of a possible future), mission statements (the role that the organization gives itself in society), overall corporate objectives (both financial and strategic), strategic business unit objectives (both financial and strategic), and tactical objectives * These objectives should, in the light of the situation analysis, suggest a strategic plan. The plan provides the details of how to achieve these objectives. ===Strategy implementation=== The implementation process requires the establishment or modification of the organizational hierarchy so that the company can achieve its objectives. The following items constitute the strategic implementation process:[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corporate_strategy] *Allocation and management of sufficient resources (financial, personnel, operational support, time, technology support) *Establishing a chain of command or some alternative structure (such as cross functional teams) *Assigning responsibility of specific tasks or processes to specific individuals or groups *It also involves managing the process. This includes monitoring results, comparing to benchmarks and best practices, evaluating the efficacy and efficiency of the process, controlling for variances, and making adjustments to the process as necessary. *When implementing specific programs, this involves acquiring the requisite resources, developing the process, training, process testing, documentation, and integration with (and/or conversion from) legacy processes. ===Strategy evaluation=== Johnson and Scholes present a model in which strategic options are evaluated against three key success criteria:[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corporate_strategy] *Suitability (would it work?) - Suitability deals with the overall rationale of the strategy. The key point to consider is whether the strategy would address the key strategic issues underlined by the organization's strategic position. *Feasibility (can it be made to work?) - Feasibility is concerned with the resources required to implement the strategy are available, can be developed or obtained. Resources include funding, people, time and information. *Acceptability (will they work it?) - Acceptability is concerned with the expectations of the identified stakeholders (mainly shareholders, employees and customers) with the expected performance outcomes, which can be return, risk and stakeholder reactions. ==Framework approach and Strategy== Causal link maps identify the causal relationships between goals. The Activity, Chatterjee and Strategy maps can easily be translated into a causal link map. The map contains all the ===Porter - Activity Map (1996)=== Porter argues firms must achieve both operational and strategic effectiveness for superior performance. Operational effectiveness means performing similar activities better than rivals perform them by better utilizing inputs. Part, but not all of this, is efficiency. Companies achieve profitability over time through strategic positioning, meaning performing different activities from rivals' or performing similar activities in a different way. Porter focus on strategy as unique activities is crucial. Firms must choose a set of activities to deliver a unique mix of value. These activities are linked and mutually reinforcing. Not only must companies choose the right activities but the essence of strategy is choosing to perform a set of activities different than rivals and are strong enough block any company that would seek the same market. What does performing different activities than rivals achieve? Companies achieve profitability over time through strategic positioning, meaning performing different activities from rivals' or performing similar activities in a different way. They achieve differentiation, which arises from the choice of activities and how they are performed. A company can outperform rivals only if it can establish a difference that it can preserve Specifically, to achieve profits companies can focus on two different types of activities. The first is for companies to provide goods or services with greater value, charge higher prices, thereby increasing revenue. The second type of activity aims to provide goods or services at a lower cost, reduce costs, thereby increasing profitability. Porter asserts that activities are the basic unit of competitive advantage. Competitive strategy is about being different. Companies must choose different sets of activities to deliver a unique mix of values. An activity map shows how a company creates value in a competitive market (Morgan et al. 2007). The map shows which activities a company must align to generate value in the market. Activity maps identify the most critical activities needed to achieve strategic objectives and the investments necessary to support these activities. Creating the map requires focusing on the most important activities while putting less important actives to the side. The final map allows us to determine what projects, programs and activates are critical for a company to achieve its strategic objectives. The goal is to identify important activities so that it will be possible to develop ways to measure how well the company is performing these activities. An example of an activity map for Southwest Airlines appears below. [[Image: Southwest Activity Map.jpg|400px |Southwest Activity Map]] The dark blue circles denote higher-order strategic offerings. The light blue circles denote activities or investments tailored to deliver it. ===Chatterjee Map=== Sayan Chatterjee advances the subject of strategy maps by switching the focus to customer outcomes instead of customer needs. "Focusing on outcomes generates a different set of questions from a focus on needs (Morgan et al 2007 page 153)". To this end the Chatterjee Map there starts (from the top) with customer outcomes. Then the focus becomes the competitive objectives necessary to achieve the customer outcomes. In essence, the Chatterjee Map rearranges the Activity Map to reflect customer outcomes. This provides a different set of objectives and capabilities compared to focusing on customer needs (Morgan et al. 2007). The Chatterjee Map contains four swimming lanes: ;Customer Outcomes :These generally correspond to the higher-order strategic offerings displayed in the Activity Map. ;Competitive Objectives :Also called strategic outcomes are the means by which a company translates core objectives into customer outcomes. ;Core Objectives :These are the leading indicators of strategic outcomes (Morgan et al. 2007). Data on lagging indicators, such as ROI, earnings per share, profit margin, etc., signals success for failure well after there is time to adjust operations. Excellence in strategic execution at the operational level will correspond to high measures on leading indicators, assuming that the Chatterjee Map is correct. Low measures on leading indicators could indicate a few problems, such as a problem with strategy-operations alignment, but always signals the need for management to take a closer look at the business. ;Execution Capabilities :These are operational resources and activities necessary to execute the strategy. The execution capabilities align with the strategy. A lack of alignment will often surface first among the leading indicators. If unchecked it will in turn will have a ripple effect, propagating up to the customer outcomes. ===Strategy Map=== Strategy maps are a way of providing a macro view of an organization's strategy, and provide it with a language in which they can describe their strategy, prior to constructing metrics to evaluate performance against their strategies (see [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strategy_map wikipedia article]). Key Performance Indicators KPI ’s are financial and non-financial measures or metrics used to help an organization define and evaluate how successful it is, typically in terms of making progress towards its long-term organizational goals (see F. John Reh). The map must show the objectives and how objectives support other objectives. Components of a strategy map: ;Four Perspectives :Financial perspective: Shareholders (profit) versus subsidizers/financers (non profit). :External Customer perspective: The customer is concerned with: ::Time ::Quality ::Performance and Service ::Cost :Internal (business) process perspective: Involves: ::Operations management processes ::Customer management processes ::Innovation processes ::Social and regulatory processes. :Learning and growth perspective: This involves developing the human, information and organizational capital. ;Themes All strategy diagrams identify important assumptions that drive the strategy. Strategy maps outline how objectives between different strategic themes and perspectives influence each other. The purpose of a strategy map is to align the strategy with daily activities. ===Causal Link Map=== "The strategy map is a visual representation of the various cause-and-effect relationships that make up the strategy." [http://www.businessintelligence.com/article.asp?id=34&pagenum=3] There are two purposes of reports #Confirming a Theory/Hypothesis regarding the business (i.e., confirm causal link) #*Why did it happen?: X-->Y #*How did it happen?: X1 -->Y2 #Running the business using Business Process Monitoring or prediction #*What may happen?: Xf -->Yf #*What happened?: X1 versus X2 This section focuses on reports designed to confirm theories or hypotheses. This is necessary in order to test the cause-and-effect relationships needed to confirm strategy. The causal link map explicitly identifies the cause-and-effect relationships between important business concepts. These relationships are important because they allow business leaders to make assumptions about the future performance of a company (Morgan et al. 2007). Perhaps the most important unifying principle behind all the strategy diagrams is that each explicitly identifies causal links. First, remember that each strategy diagram is an explicit, tangible model designed to capture strategy. To capture strategy each diagram/model explicitly identifies important assumptions that drive the strategy. These assumptions are either a/an: #Objective #Activity #Link between objectives or activities However, without a means to achieve an objective, or a direction for activity, the company could not function effectively. So, the company links activities and objectives. For instance: * Quicker terminal turnaround (activity) translates into on-time delivery (objective) * Closing railroad crossings (activity) translates into fewer accidents (objective) * Minimizing maintenance costs (objective) translates into higher profits (objective) Each of the bulleted items above is a causal link. The Activity Diagram, Chatterjee Map and Strategy Map all contain these types of links. In essence, each type of diagram assumes causal links. The difference between the diagrams is simply based on the perspective it brings to understanding the strategy. The activity diagram identifies important higher-order strategic offerings and the activities or investments necessary to execute. The Chatterjee Map "made a significant contribution to the subject of strategy maps by overlaying a subtle but crucial distinction between a focus on customer outcomes versus customer needs." Finally, Norton and Kaplan Strategy Maps offer a process, when combined with scorecards, with the ability to translate specific objectives into leading indicators that help determine if objectives are being met (Morgan et al. 2007). This helps the decision maker identify those initiatives that will allow the company to achieve its objectives. Given that all strategy maps contains objectives, activities and links, it is possible to turn any strategy diagram into a causal link map. Therefore, the unifying principle behind strategy diagrams is that they can all be translated into causal link maps. The causal link map explicitly identifies the cause-and-effect relationships between important business concepts. Identifying these relationships is important because they not only allow business leaders to make assumptions about the future performance of a company but also provide them with the means to test these assumptions. A strategy map is only useful if its empirically testable assumptions are accurate. The section on scorecards will describe how to test these assumptions.

page.title: Parent Education Course Writer's Guide/Example rules for a family council

revision.comment: +category
revision.text:
== Democracy ==
The family council is recognized as a democratic committee.
* Every family member has one vote. * Decisions are made in open ballots. Secret ballots can be decided with a [[wikipedia:simple majority|simple majority]]. * All decisions require a simple majority unless the rules ask for [[wikipedia:consensus|consensus]]. * Family members who feel they have been to passed over and have lost in a voting can request a second vote for a later voting. To award the second vote a simple majority is sufficient. Only one further vote per voter is possible but can be preserved indefinitely. * Changes to these rules require consensus. * Parents have a [[wikipedia:veto|right of veto]] but it requires the consensus of the parents.
=== Appointments ===
* The initiator of an appointment is the chairman and allows others to speak. * The chairman should present an [[wikipedia:agenda|agenda]] one day before an appointment, the adherence of which can be demanded. * An appointment can be postponed for one week. Family members who cannot keep an appointment that is supported by a majority are responsible to make a new appointment. The office of chairman is not affected by this and remains with the original initiator. * The family council can demand willingness for discussions of up to two hours per week. * An appointment requires consensus of the participants. * A family member not attending a meeting of the council can delegate his or her vote to another family member without explanation but only if the decision is made in advance.
=== Discussions ===
* Opinions must be explained, which requires the word "because". * An opinion can be rejected as not conclusive, which requires a single majority. Unsubstantiated opinions are ignored; the same applies to resulting votes. * Explanations about the topics being discussed can be demanded by every participant and must be given. If a relevant explanation is not given the family council is no longer quorate (competent to make decisions). The chairman also allows others to speak when explanations are given.
== Assignment of tasks ==
* The family council can assign and withdraw household tasks and obligations. * The family council can use a [[wikipedia:Job_rotation|rotation system]] for tasks. * Assigned household tasks should not exceed four hours per week. * The family council can impose a penalty of another four hours per week upon disregard of the council.
== Budgets and other resources ==
* Expenditures and the distribution of other resources can be regulated in the family council. * Usage of rooms, pocket money, choice of meals, computer time and TV time can be seen as resources.
== Lists ==
The following lists are annotations to the rules of the family council and can be changed in consensus only.
=== List of problems ===
Problems are meant to be seen as [[wikipedia:anti-pattern|anti-pattern]]s the family council has agreed to prevent.
=== List of decisions ===
Decisions are important choices the family council has agreed to append to the rules of the council as a reminder.
{{BookCat}}

TOTAL SCORE: 48 /50
== Comments (1 + 1) ==
Provide ONE compliment and ONE suggestion for your peer reviewer. For example, what did you find most or least effective? What would make the feedback more effective?
I really appreciated the comments made by the peer reviewer. I felt that they are very achievable and will certainly do my best to improve my article. I thought that the most effective comment was that I should expand my FAQ page. I felt that I covered all bases, but I can now see that there is room for more relevant information.
With this being a FAQ page, I have a hard time putting in a lot of my own thoughts/opinions. Perhaps a section at the bottom would remedy this by giving me an opportunity to express my thoughts but still keeping the FAQ clean and free of opinions or bias.
[[User:Alucy001|Alucy001]] ([[User talk:Alucy001|talk]]) 01:07, 19 June 2009 (UTC)

I think that this peer reviewer did an excellent job of reviwing my article. It was easy to understand, and gave me specific details that I could use to improve my article. However, I am having a hard time with one of the suggestions that was given. The suggestion was that I should add more opinions and personal touches to the article. I can see more of that in the other types of special feature articles, but have a hard time putting a lot of opinions and such in the Chapter FAQ. Suggestion - Make sure to use to rubric in your reviews. While you quoted them in your ratings, sometimes it helps to see where you fall on the actual rubric diagram.

revision.text:
<big><center><big><font color="#0066CC">'''PEER REVIEW FEEDBACK'''</big></big></font> *Use this template to grade the peer reviews you receive.</center>
Directions
*Use this rubric to evaluate EACH peer review you receive for your article. *You will award points for each of the sections in this rubric. *Write the scores below in the section called "Scores". *Your evaluation will determine your reviewer's grade for this assignment; please take your time and grade honestly and fairly. -----------------
{| border="1" |+ <big> '''Foundations Wiki Article Peer Review Feedback: Grading Rubric''' </big> |<center>'''Assessment Criterion'''|| <center>'''Level of Performance''' ||. || . || |- | . || <center>Complete (30) || <center>Incomplete (0-29)||.|| |- | <center>'''Includes All Components''' || Feedback is provided for ALL of the following sections: *Learning targets (2 points) *Multiple-choice questions (2 points) *Sources (2 points) *Rating (2 points) *Explanation of rating (5 points) *Grammar/mechanics (5 points) *Includes two compliments (4 points) *Includes two suggestions (4 points) *Contains 150 words total or more (4 points) ||The full point value should be deducted for any missing components. Partial credit can be awarded for incomplete components. ||. |- | . || <center>'''Above Average 5'''|| <center>''' Average 4'''|| <center>'''Needs Improvement 0 to 3'''|| |- | . || . || .||.|| |- |- |<center>'''Reflects Standards or Criteria'''|| Feedback specifically describes how the paper meets or does not meet the criteria listed in the rubric|| Feedback generally relates to the criteria listed in the rubric|| Feedback is unrelated to the criteria listed in the rubric|| |- |<center>'''Understandable''' || Feedback is written in a clear and direct manner that is easy to understand || Some of the feedback is clear; some is vague, confusing or difficult to understand || The feedback is vague, confusing or difficult to understand || |- |<center>'''Specific'''||Many specific passages in the text are referred to as strengths and/or weaknesses||At least one specific passage in the text is noted as a strength or weaknesses; much of the feedback is general||The feedback is general; it does not reference specific passages of the text as strong or weak points|| |- |<center>'''Achievable'''||The feedback is positively stated and includes several suggestions that can be reasonably made by the author to improve the quality of the article||The feedback contains at least one reasonable suggestion; may also contain suggestions that are unrealistic given the capabilities of the author/the time allotted for revision||Feedback contains no specific suggestions to achieve or only contains suggestions that are unrealistic given the capabilities of the author/the time allotted for revision|| |- |.|| .|| . || .||
|}
== SCORES ==
*Includes all components: _______ / 30
*Reflects Standards or Criteria: _______ / 5
*Understandable: _______ / 5
*Specific: _______ / 5
*Achievable: _______ / 5
TOTAL SCORE: _______ /50
== Comments (1 + 1) ==
Provide ONE compliment and ONE suggestion for your peer reviewer. For example, what did you find most or least effective? What would make the feedback more effective?

revision.text: __NOTOC__ ==About this book== This book is brought to you by many [[Java Programming/Authors & Contributors|authors and contributors]] as well as anonymous editors. ==Introduction== This book is an introduction to programming in [http://www.oracle.com/us/technologies/java/index.htm Oracle-Sun’s Java™ programming language], a widely used programming language and software platform. This book serves as a comprehensive guide, complete with a [[Java Programming/Tutorials|series of tutorials]] to help users better understand the many ways one can program in Java. In its entirety, this book is meant to be both an introductory guide and a useful reference on Java and related technologies. As is the nature of this book, the content within the book is continuously being updated and revised. With every chapter within this book, the complexity of the context increases, building up on lessons learnt in the previous chapters. Beginners should therefore start from the beginning and proceed in a sequence throughout the material of the book. Other special purpose books on Java, such as Java Enterprise Edition programming, [[Java Persistence]], or Java Swing programming, with more details, would complement this book nicely. {{-}} ==Table of Contents== ==={{stage short|75%|03 Mar 2010}} [[Java Programming/Introduction|Introduction]]=== : {{stage short|25%|03 Mar 2010}} [[Java Programming/Introduction#How This Book is Organized|How This revision.text:
{{Wikipedia|Islam in Syria}}
* The Syrian law is positive law which uses many of the French law as resource. * The Syrian president belong to the Alawi sector wish is part of Shiaa sectors and keep the power between them.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/hi/arabic/middle_east_news/newsid_4462000/4462070.stm Alawis minority in Syria are afraid of the future] ar</ref><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/hi/arabic/middle_east_news/newsid_4319000/4319069.stm who rules in Syria?] ar</ref><ref>[http://www.islamway.com/?iw_s=Article&iw_a=view&article_id=3891 /Article about Nassiret] ar</ref><ref>[http://www.gom.com.eg/algomhuria/2008/09/12/editor/ Egypt Future] ar</ref><ref>[http://alaweenonline.com/content/view/38/52/ Alawi and the Rule in Syria] ar</ref>
* There is prostitution in known area of Damascus<ref>[http://www.free-syria.com/loadarticle.php?articleid=5508 The Iraqi prostitution spread in Syria] ar</ref><ref>[http://www.syria-news.com/readnews.php?sy_seq=7827 The corruptness of the family that govern Syria "Syria's New Mafia" - no 9: Atef Najeeb] ar</ref>
====Supporting Shiataization==== The regimen in Syria is accused of supporting Shiataization and some say that it's because of the joined origions of Shia Alawi and the Shia the Twelfth (Imami). <ref>[http://ahmedzaidan.maktoobblog.com/972526/%D8%AF%D8%B1%D8%A7%D8%B3%D8%A9-%D8%AA%D9%83%D8%B4%D9%81-%D8%AD%D9%82%D8%A7%D8%A6%D9%82-%D9%85%D8%B0%D9%87%D9%84%D8%A9-%D8%B9%D9%86-%D9%85%D8%B4%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%B9-%D8%AA%D8%B4%D9%8A%D9%8A%D8%B9/ Study about shiataization in Syria] The Movement for Building and Justis (Syrian Opposition) ar</ref> <ref>[http://www.syriakurds.com/sheasy.htm Shiataization file in Syrian Kurds site] ar</ref><ref>[http://www.free-syria.com/print.php?articleid=26981 Words for previous vice-presedent (Abdel-Halim Khaddam)] ar</ref><ref>[http://http://www.gom.com.eg/algomhuria/2006/10/26/editor/detail00.shtml Iranian bribe for Arab countries - Egyptian online newspaper] ar</ref><ref>[http://www.odabasham.net/show.php?sid=10357 Iranian brech of the Arab world - Association of Al-Sham Authors] ar</ref><ref>[http://www.alkadhum.org/alfurat/news/pages/content.php?contid=57 Shiataization spreading in Sunnis African countries] ar</ref><ref>[http://pulpit.alwatanvoice.com/content-149166.html Manifestations of the penetration of Shiism in Sunnis countries] Dar Alwatan Article ar</ref> but the official Mofti and the Shia references deny that. <ref>[http://www.islamonline.net/servlet/Satellite?c=ArticleA_C&cid=1209358088965&pagename=Zone-Arabic-ArtCulture%2FACALayout No Shiataization by money] Shia reference Abdullah Nizam statment ar</ref><ref>[http://www.islamonline.net/servlet/Satellite?c=ArticleA_C&pagename=Zone-Arabic-ArtCulture%2FACALayout&cid=1212925105868 Speaking of Shiataization is exaggerated- Mofti Ahmad Hassoun] ar</ref>

[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]

== [[Unlingvae]] == As requested, I've gone over your book's wording and corrected typos or errors where I found them. I also improved the use of your question and answer templates so they are easier to edit and use wiki code to achieve the same effect. The answers were also too small to read because of the tag around them. I put tables around the questions and answers and gave the tables a fixed width so they do not extend all the way across the screen unnecessarily. Additionally, I gave the question and answer table rows a fixed height so the text on the page does not bounce up and down when an answer is shown. I improved the code of the pages and made it so your vocabulary tables sit side-by-side instead of top-to-bottom. I added a horizontal rule above your navigation to improve the appearance. I think the book looks quite good now. -- [[User:Adrignola|Adrignola]] [[User talk:Adrignola|talk]] [[Special:Contributions/Adrignola|contribs]] 03:17, 6 June 2009 (UTC) ==[[:Phaehrae]]== {{mbox|type=warning|msg= '''[[:Phaehrae|Phaehrae]] has been nominated for deletion. Please [[WB:VFD#Phaehrae|share your thoughts]].'''
You are being notified because you have contributed to this work. If you haven't already, please see our [[WB:DP|deletion policy]]. [[User:Cilantrohead|Cilantrohead]] ([[User talk:Cilantrohead|talk]]) 04:23, 17 September 2009 (UTC)}}

{{TODO| * Add in 60:8 or 60:13 to support not being "friendly" to nonbelievers mocking/criticizing * Death threats against Geert Wilders - is there anything in the quran about this? * Any significance with others that planned the death of Van Gogh? * Briefly discuss Fitna to support Wilders criticism and the Muslim animosity towards the film (e.g., using far extremist and revered quotes) }}
In 2004, Theo Van Gogh directed the film, "Submission"<ref>Wikipedia entry for [[w:Submission_(film)|Fitna]]</ref>. Even though the movie was a fictional story about a muslim woman, the story was based on the interpretation of the Koran and centred in role of muslim women. Later that year, Van Gogh was murdered by a muslim named Mohammed Bouyeri<ref>[[w:Mohammed Bouyeri]]</ref>. The author, muslim-turned-atheist Ayaan Hirsi Ali, is still criticized by the Muslim leadership for her criticism of Islam, including death threats.<ref>http://pittsburghlive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/news/rss/print_503977.html Furor over author Ayaan Hirsi Ali's visit stirs debate on religious freedom</ref><ref>http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nUXpYswi7ck Ayaan Hirsi Ali death threats -France24 EN</ref>
In 2008, Geert Wilders released a film called Fitna<ref>[[w:Fitna_(film)]]</ref>. The film argued that Islam encourages acts of terrorism, antisemitism, and violence against women and homosexuals.<ref>[http://www.islamhouse.com/tp/107068 The anti-Islam Dutch film – comment, criticism and advice]</ref>
<references/>

revision.comment: About Netherlands
revision.text: * A film argues that Islam encourages acts of terrorism, antisemitism, violence against women and homosexuals was made in Holland.<ref>[[w:Fitna_(film)]]</ref><ref>[http://www.islamhouse.com/tp/107068 The anti-Islam Dutch film – comment, criticism and advice]</ref> * Same-sex marriages have been performed and recognised in the Netherlands since 1 April 2001. The Netherlands was the first country to do so.<ref>[[W:Same-sex marriage in the Netherlands]]</ref> * Prostitution in the Netherlands is legal.<ref>[[w:Prostitution_in_the_Netherlands]]</ref>In 2003 it was estimated that in Amsterdam, one woman in 35 was working as prostitute, compared to one in 300 in London.<ref>[http://www.swissinfo.org/eng/front/Window_ban_for_Zurich_s_prostitutes.html?siteSect=107&sid=1853267&cKey=1052980380000&ty=st]</ref> * Abortion in the Netherlands is currently legal on demand with a five-day waiting period.<ref>[[W:Abortion_in_the_Netherlands]]</ref> * In 2002, the Netherlands legalized euthanasia.<ref>[[W:Euthanasia_in_the_Netherlands]]</ref> ==references== <references/>

{{Wikipedia|Islam in the United States}} == In conformity with the Quran == * Muslims have more freedoms in the USA than in some Arab or Muslim countries.
== In contradiction with the Quran == * Supports Israel. Israel has fought a series of wars with neighboring Arab states, and in consequence, Israel controls territories beyond those delineated in the 1949 Armistice Agreements. * Permits the public expression of sexual acts. * Permits torture. <ref>[http://www.almoslim.net/node/111400 التعذيب الديمقراطي,موقع المسلم]</ref> * Has no alcohol prohibition. * Land of cinema ,movies and video clips. {{TODO|Some of these items need a rewrite to be directly related to the subject matter. Supporting Israel is problematic but not directly against the Quran, probably linking it to a similar list on Israel and then explain what are the violations.|Islam In The World}}
== External opinions == * Many Muslims perceive that US cultural, political and economic hegemony as enemy number one.
==References== <references/>
[[ar:مستخدم:الحارث بن همام/حقوق الله/الولايات المتحدة]]
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]] [http://www.example.com link title]

== In conformity with the Quran == * Men are ordered to pray in the Mosques. and shops are ordered to be closed at pray time. * Sharia Laws are applied. * There is an official authority called "'''The General Presidency of the promotion of virtue and the prevention of vice'''" to help enforcing Sharia. * There is office dedicated to inform about Islam and the Islamic activities, that works also with workers that came from foreign countries. * Wine is banned. * Bars and night clubs are banned. * Women are ordered to wear the Islamic clothes.
== In contradiction with the Quran == * Non-Muslims are allowed to live in the country even though the Prophet Mohammad said before his death to move them of the Arabic peninsula <ref>[http://islamqa.com/ar/ref/104806 Islam question and answers site]</ref><ref>Bukhari Book,3618</ref>
==references== <references/>
